column1: HUT 8 RIVERBEND - DATA HALL COMMISSIONING WBS
Project: Hut 8 Riverbend Data Center - 224 MW Facility
Scope: Level 4-5 Commissioning Execution for Single 36 MW Data Hall Block
Levels Covered: L4 (Functional Performance Testing + Heat Load Testing + System Level Testing) | L5 (Integrated Systems Testing)

column7: Notes
Direct execution of electrical system commissioning: transformers, switchgear, UPS, batteries
Direct execution of mechanical system commissioning: chillers, CDUs, CRAH, cooling systems
Hands-on electrical testing and data collection
Hands-on mechanical testing and equipment setup
Cross-discipline support and schedule flexibility
Peak demand support and backup
Primary commissioning execution team on-site daily
Program oversight, vendor coordination, client interface. Oversees and directs all L4-L5 commissioning activities.
Documentation QA/QC, report generation, scheduling support (50% allocation during L4-L5)
Program-level support (not dedicated solely to this block)
10 site + 1 Cx Mgr + 0.5 Doc Coord

column1: Note: CxA performs full execution of L4-L5 commissioning activities per RFP scope definition
Level 4 – IST Duration: No more than six (6) weeks per 36 MW block
Critical Question (RFI-001.01): Does 6-week constraint apply to:
This WBS assumes: 6 weeks applies to combined L4+L5 based on RFP wording "Level 4 – IST"

column2: - Total: 5.5-6.5 weeks (targeting 6 weeks for this WBS)

column1: WORK BREAKDOWN STRUCTURE - L4-L5 EXECUTION (6 WEEKS)

column7: Cx Mgr
50 hrs/wk

column2: L4 kickoff meeting with Owner and GC
Review L1-L3 punch list and verify substantial completion
Finalize L4 test procedures and sequence

column3: Insulation resistance (megger), turns ratio, polarity, power factor/tan delta, winding resistance, temperature rise testing, protective relay settings verification and testing
Same as IT transformers, larger capacity, more complex relay coordination

column2: Ring Main Unit Functional Testing (23 units)

column3: Primary/secondary injection testing of protective relays, breaker timing, contact resistance, insulation resistance, operational sequences
Extensive relay testing, coordination verification, interlocks, SCADA integration, metering accuracy
Full operational testing, capacity verification, control sequences, safeties, economizer operation, staging. Load testing coordinated with CDU/CRAH systems.
Flow verification, temperature stratification monitoring, level controls, isolation valves. Integrated with chiller loop testing.
System-level chilled water loop testing, flow balancing verification (TAB by others - oversight only), temperature differential verification

column2: LV Switchboard Functional Testing - Electrical (32 units)

column3: 480V main distribution: breaker testing, protective device coordination, ground fault, arc flash verification, load balancing, metering

column2: LV Switchboard Functional Testing - Mechanical (12 units)

column3: Higher ampacity mechanical boards: more extensive load testing and coordination verification required
Modular UPS: full functional test including bypass operation, load transfer, battery discharge, parallel operation, alarms, monitoring. Most labor-intensive electrical activity.
Li-ion battery strings: BMS verification, cell voltage monitoring, temperature monitoring, discharge testing (statistical sampling per IEEE standards), isolation verification

column2: CRAH Fan Wall Testing - Electrical Rooms (11 units)

column3: Fan wall: airflow measurement, control sequences, VFD operation, temperature/humidity monitoring, staging algorithms. TAB by others - oversight only.
Cooling distribution: flow/pressure testing, temperature differential verification, control sequences, leak testing, valve operation. Integrated testing with CRAH and chillers.

column2: CRAH Fan Wall Testing - Data Halls (36 units)

column3: Data hall fan walls: airflow measurement and balancing (TAB by others - oversight), control integration, VFD testing, staging sequences, temperature control
Containment: pressure verification, door interlocks, monitoring system integration, airflow patterns

column2: Rack Power Panel Functional Testing (160 units)

column3: Rack PDU: breaker verification, metering accuracy, remote monitoring, load testing, branch circuit verification. High quantity drives schedule.
RDP: functional testing, breaker coordination, monitoring, feeder verification
Complete electrical distribution system testing: load balancing across all switchboards, transfer scenarios, protective device coordination verification end-to-end, ground fault system verification
Complete cooling system testing: chiller staging and load following, CDU distribution uniformity, CRAH airflow balancing across all units, temperature stratification, economizer modes
Coordinate load bank setup (provided/operated by others), review load bank plans, pre-test walkdown, safety verification

column2: Note: WBS shows Week 6 only (575 hrs). Additional 0.5 week (287.5 hrs) would extend to 6.5 weeks total if needed.
Redundancy verification (N+1 or 2N depending on design)
Load bank setup and safety verification (by others - CxA oversight)
Steady-state operation at target load (typically 80-90% for initial operation)
Cooling system response verification during load ramp
Integration with CxAlloy or Facility Grid platform (per RFI-001.02)
Generator start testing (if applicable - not in RFP equipment list)

column4: Kickoff, outdoor electrical equipment (transformers, RMUs, MV switchboards), outdoor mechanical equipment startup (chillers)
Outdoor electrical completion, outdoor mechanical (chillers, buffer tanks, chilled water system), indoor electrical startup (LV switchboards, UPS)
Indoor electrical (UPS 113 units, batteries 351 units), indoor mechanical startup (CRAH elec rooms, CDU)
Indoor electrical completion, indoor mechanical (CDUs 32 units, CRAH data halls 36 units), white space power distribution startup (rack power panels)
White space power completion (160 rack panels), system-level testing (electrical & mechanical), heat load test prep

Integrated systems testing: electrical system integration, mechanical system integration, IT load simulation testing (load banks), monitoring integration (BMS/EPMS/DCIM), emergency scenarios (EPO, failures), closeout & turnover
L4: Weeks 1-5 (functional, heat load, system testing) | L5: Week 6 (integrated systems testing)

column6: Compressed from typical 8-10 weeks to 5 weeks. Requires efficient execution and 10-person site crew.
Compressed from typical 2-3 weeks to 1 week. Requires load banks ready and no major deficiencies from L4.
Achieves RFP 6-week constraint with 10-person site crew and strong management coordination. Minimal schedule contingency.

column2: - 6-week duration is feasible but aggressive compared to industry standards (54% schedule compression)
- Requires: No major equipment deficiencies from L4

column3: 6.5-7 weeks more realistic. Build flexibility into contract terms per pricing assumptions.

column3: L3 complete, piping systems pressure tested/flushed/filled
column5: HIGH - Large chiller quantity drives schedule
HIGH - High UPS quantity (113 units) is schedule driver

column3: Outdoor mechanical complete, chilled water available
column5: MEDIUM - Dependent on chiller commissioning completion
MEDIUM - High quantity but straightforward testing
MEDIUM - Cannot start until all equipment passes L4

column3: All L4 complete, load banks available and operational
column5: CRITICAL - Load bank availability and readiness

column1: Overall Critical Path: Outdoor Elec (2w) → Indoor Elec (3w overlaps with Outdoor Mech) → System Testing (1w) → L5 IST (1w) = 6 weeks minimum

column2: Transformers (44 units), RMUs (23 units), MV SWBDs (2)
column4: Electrical and mechanical teams work in parallel on different systems. Both can proceed simultaneously.

column2: Complete outdoor electrical, LV switchboards startup (44 units)
column3: Chillers continued (27 units), Buffer tanks (27), Chilled water system
column4: Continued parallel execution. Electrical moves indoors while mechanical completes outdoor equipment.

column2: UPS functional testing (113 units), Battery testing startup (351 sampling)
column3: CRAH elec rooms (11 units), CDU startup (32 units)
column4: UPS testing is most labor-intensive electrical activity. Mechanical starts indoor equipment commissioning.

column2: Complete UPS and batteries, Rack power panels startup (160 units)
column3: CDU continued (32 units), CRAH data halls (36 units), Hot aisle containment (11)
column4: High equipment quantities in both disciplines require full crews. Some cross-discipline support for containment.

column2: Complete rack power panels (160), RDPs (7 units), Electrical system-level testing
column3: Complete CRAH and CDUs, Mechanical system-level testing, Heat load test prep
column4: Disciplines converge for system-level testing. Teams coordinate for integrated testing preparation.
Fully integrated testing: both disciplines work together on load testing, monitoring, emergency scenarios

column1: Critical Vendor Coordination: Chiller vendor startup (27 units) is critical path item. Must pre-schedule and confirm availability.

column2: 1. 6-week duration based on RFP constraint "Level 4 – IST Duration: No more than six (6) weeks per 36 MW block"
2. Assumes 6-week constraint applies to combined L4+L5 per RFI-001.01 (critical question requiring clarification)
3. L4 duration: 5 weeks (Functional Performance Testing + Heat Load Testing + System Level Testing)
4. L5 duration: 1 week (Integrated Systems Testing) - aggressive but achievable if L4 goes smoothly
5. 10-person site crew working 50 hours/week provides adequate capacity for 6-week timeline
6. Equipment has been properly energized and L3 pre-functional testing substantially complete before L4 start
7. Mechanical systems dominate schedule due to high equipment count and sequential dependencies (chillers → CDUs → CRAH)

column4: and TAB performed by others; PGCIS oversight only per scope assumptions

column2: 9. Load banks provided and operated by others; PGCIS load bank plan review and oversight only per scope assumptions
10. Weather contingency NOT explicitly included - assume indoor work can proceed during outdoor weather delays
11. Vendor support pre-coordinated 4-6 weeks before L4 start to avoid delays
12. Commissioning management platform (CxAlloy or Facility Grid) used per RFI-001.02 for test data and documentation

column4: Cannot complete L4+L5 in 6 weeks if RFP constraint interpreted strictly
column5: RFI-001.01 CRITICAL question - must clarify scope of 6-week constraint before finalizing schedule

column4: Retest time extends L4 schedule, may exceed 6-week window
column5: 15% contingency typically required. Include contractual language about L3 substantial completion requirements.

column5: Efficient test procedures, vendor support for initial units, potential for parallel testing with full crew

column4: BMS/EPMS/DCIM integration problems delay L5 IST
column5: Early integration testing during L4, controls contractor support, dedicated integration time in Week 6
